name: design-principles
summary: GoA Design System expert principles and decision frameworks for teams and designers
purpose: Provide comprehensive guidance for design decisions, pattern selection, and system governance

core.description: All design decisions must prioritize citizen and worker needs over aesthetic preferences
core.application: Choose components and patterns based on user research and government service requirements
examples: Use one question per page for citizen forms to reduce cognitive load
Provide bulk operations for worker tools to improve efficiency
Include clear progress indicators for multi-step processes

core.description: WCAG 2.2 AA compliance is non-negotiable, not an add-on
core.application: Use GoA components which provide built-in accessibility features
examples: Always wrap form inputs with GoabFormItem for proper labeling
Use semantic HTML structure provided by GoA components
Ensure color contrast meets government standards

core.description: Consistent user experience across government services trumps unique design
core.application: Use established GoA patterns rather than inventing new ones
examples: Follow GoabOneColumnLayout for all government pages
Use standard GoA header and footer components
Apply consistent spacing and typography tokens

core.description: Leverage existing GoA components before considering custom solutions
core.application: Exhaust GoA component library options before building custom components
examples: Use GoabTable with sorting for data display rather than custom tables
Combine existing components creatively before building new ones
Contribute back to the design system if you identify genuine gaps

citizen.description: Citizens use government services infrequently and need maximum clarity
guidelines: Plain language at grade 9 reading level

citizen.description: Citizens often access services on mobile devices
guidelines: Consider data usage and slow connections

worker.description: Workers use these tools daily and need to be productive
guidelines: Provide keyboard shortcuts and quick actions
Enable rapid decision-making with clear data presentation

worker.description: Workers need context to make good decisions for citizens
guidelines: Show relevant case history and status
Provide clear action options with consequences

questions: What is the user trying to accomplish?
Is this a citizen or worker task?
Are there existing patterns for this need?
Does a GoA component directly solve this need?
What do similar government services use?
What does the recipe library suggest?
Does this meet WCAG 2.2 AA standards?
Can users with disabilities complete this task?
Does it work with screen readers?
How will this component be maintained?
Does the team have expertise to support it?
Can this scale across multiple projects?

redFlags: Building custom components without exhausting GoA options
Creating one-off solutions that can't be reused

forms.complex: Multi-step with GoabFormStepper and progress indication
considerations: Save progress capability for long forms

information.simple: GoabContainer with GoabText and GoabCallout for highlights
information.complex: GoabAccordion or GoabDetails for progressive disclosure

dashboard.pattern: GoabTable with GoabBadge status indicators and bulk operations
considerations: Information density appropriate for daily use

caseManagement.pattern: GoabTabs with GoabContainer sections and action buttons

designDecisions.description: Building custom solutions when GoA components exist
designDecisions.why: Increases maintenance burden and reduces consistency
designDecisions.solution: Exhaustively search GoA library and recipes before building custom

designDecisions.description: Using citizen-optimized patterns for worker interfaces
designDecisions.solution: Use appropriate patterns for each user type

designDecisions.why: Results in retrofitting and compliance failures
designDecisions.solution: Use GoA components which provide accessibility by default
designDecisions.detection: Custom components without proper ARIA attributes

designDecisions.why: Breaks government service consistency and branding
designDecisions.solution: Always use GoabOneColumnLayout with proper header/footer

technicalImplementation.description: Using multiple frontend frameworks in one project
technicalImplementation.solution: Choose React or Angular and stick to it

technicalImplementation.description: Using CSS to override GoA component appearance
technicalImplementation.why: Breaks design system consistency and future updates
technicalImplementation.solution: Use component props and GoA design tokens
technicalImplementation.detection: Custom CSS targeting GoA component classes

whenToUseDesignReview: Before starting implementation of new features
When adapting existing patterns to new contexts
whenToRecommendPatterns: Team is unsure which components to use
Multiple design approaches are being considered
Need to optimize for specific user type
Want to ensure government service best practices
whenToAuditAccessibility: Before public release of citizen-facing services
governanceCheckTriggers: Multiple teams working on related projects

responsibilities: Bridge communication between design and development

contributions: Define user needs and acceptance criteria
Balance feature complexity with user experience
Create designs using GoA component library

designPhase: Use GoA Figma library for initial designs
Review designs with design system expert
developmentPhase: Review code for design system compliance
